deliberation: Examined whether formulaic terms like 'the word that came' (הַדָּבָר אֲשֶׁר הָיָה) or the geographic listing might be metonymic or figurative. Concluded this opening superscription is standard narrative formula with literal geography and no clear figurative usage beyond routine prophetic diction.

Considered whether 'all the evil that I brought' (כׇּל־הָרָעָה) or 'they are a ruin today' (וְהִנָּם חָרְבָּה) are figurative. Here they refer to actual historical devastation of Jerusalem and Judah's towns; 'evil' in the sense of calamity is lexical. No strong metaphor, simile, or personification beyond standard prophetic prose.

Looked at 'to vex/provoke Me' (לְהַכְעִסֵנִי) as an anthropopathic representation of God being angered by idolatry. This assigns a human psychological reaction to God. No other metaphors or similes appear.

instances.english_text: to vex Me / to provoke Me
ground: being personally affronted and angered by another's behavior
relational offense and displeasure
shared social-emotional experience
posture: condemnation of idolatry as personally offensive to God
instances.explanation: The verb 'to vex/provoke Me' attributes to God a human-like experience of being deliberately irritated, an anthropopathic way of expressing divine displeasure.

deliberation: Focused on the expression 'הַשְׁכֵּים וְשָׁלֹחַ' ('rising early and sending') for God's dispatching of prophets. This is a stock Jeremianic idiom that pictures God as a human householder rising early to send messengers, an anthropomorphic and idiomatic way to stress persistence and urgency.

instances.english_text: persistently (lit. 'rising early and sending')
vehicle: a person who gets up early to send messengers
ground: eagerness, persistence, priority-giving to a task
constant, timely effort
shared human experience of early rising for important work
posture: portrays God as extraordinarily diligent in warning them, intensifying their guilt
instances.explanation: The idiom 'rising early and sending' metaphorically depicts God's persistence and urgency in sending prophets as if He were a human master up early to dispatch servants.

deliberation: Considered two expressions: (1) 'inclined not their ear' (לֹא־הִטּוּ אֶת־אׇזְנָם) as idiomatic for refusing attentive obedience, and (2) 'to turn back from their wickedness' (לָשׁוּב מֵרָעָתָם) as the standard path/turning metaphor for repentance. Both are figurative, distinct conceptualizations.

instances.english_text: they did not incline their ear
target: the people's refusal to heed the prophets
vehicle: tilting one's ear toward a speaker
ground: attentive openness versus deliberate inattention
physical posture as indicator of receptivity
shared communicative behavior
posture: criticizes them for willful inattention to divine warning
instances.explanation: The idiom 'to incline the ear' pictures obedience as physically leaning one's ear toward a speaker, so their failure to do so figuratively depicts stubborn refusal to heed.

instances.english_text: to turn back from their wickedness
vehicle: turning back from a path or journey
ground: change of course from one direction to another
reversal and reorientation
shared experience of walking/travel
posture: frames repentance as a decisive change of direction away from evil
instances.explanation: Using the common 'turn back' verb for repentance, wicked behavior is conceptualized as a wrong path from which one must reverse course.

deliberation: Identified two vivid images of divine anger: (1) 'my wrath and my anger were poured out' (וַתִּתַּךְ חֲמָתִי וְאַפִּי) treating anger as a liquid, and (2) 'it burned in the cities' (וַתִּבְעַר בְּעָרֵי יְהוּדָה) treating wrath as fire. Both are standard prophetic metaphors for judgment, not literal physical fluids or flames from God.

instances.english_text: so My fierce anger was poured out
target: YHWH's act of judgment against Judah
vehicle: fluid that can be tipped out in quantity
ground: sudden, forceful, overwhelming release
uncontainable outpouring
shared experience of liquid being dumped out
posture: emphasizes the severity and totality of judgment as an unstoppable outpouring
instances.explanation: God's wrath is metaphorically depicted as a liquid that is poured out, highlighting its intensity and the completeness of the judgment.

instances.english_text: and it blazed against the towns of Judah and the streets of Jerusalem
target: the effect of God's wrath on Judah's cities
vehicle: a fire blazing in cities and streets
ground: consuming, devastating spread; leaving ruins behind
intense heat and destruction
shared experience of fire's effects
posture: presents judgment as a consuming fire engulfing the community
instances.explanation: Divine anger is described as a blaze burning through the cities, personifying wrath as an active, destructive fire.

deliberation: Looked for totalizing or idiomatic patterns. The sequence 'man and woman, child and suckling' (אִישׁ־וְאִשָּׁה עוֹלֵל וְיוֹנֵק) functions as a merism, enumerating all demographic groups to express complete annihilation. No separate metaphors or similes.

instances.english_text: every man and woman, child and infant
vehicle: a comprehensive pair of gender and age contrasts
ground: inclusive span from male to female, from infant to older child
communicates totality through extremes and pairs
shared use of lists to denote 'everyone'
posture: underscores that no segment of the people will escape judgment
instances.explanation: By pairing male/female and child/nursing infant, the text uses merism to convey that the entire community, without exception, is threatened with being cut off.

deliberation: Noted two figurative elements: (1) 'the work of your hands' (מַעֲשֵׂי יְדֵיכֶם) as synecdoche/metonymy for their deeds or cultic practices, and (2) 'to be a curse and a reproach among all nations' (לִקְלָלָה וּלְחֶרְפָּה) where 'curse' and 'reproach' stand metonymically for being objects of cursing and mockery.

instances.english_text: by your deeds (lit. 'by the work of your hands')
vehicle: the physical work performed by one's hands
ground: hands as primary instruments of doing
what the hands make/do represents the whole deed
common synecdoche for action
posture: highlights that their concrete, deliberate acts provoke God
instances.explanation: Referring to 'the work of your hands' uses the hands as a synecdoche for the totality of their deeds, especially their manufactured idols and rituals.

instances.hebrew_text: וּלְמַעַן הֱיוֹתְכֶם לִקְלָלָה וּלְחֶרְפָּה בְּכֹל גּוֹיֵ הָאָרֶץ
instances.english_text: so that you may become a curse and a mockery among all the nations of the earth
target: Judah's reputation and fate among the nations
ground: those under judgment become proverbial examples used in cursing and mocking
identity reduced to being a byword of disgrace
shared use of names as negative examples
posture: warns that their destiny will be to serve as a negative proverb among the nations
instances.explanation: To 'become a curse and a mockery' means they will be so notorious for disaster that their name is used metonymically in others' curses and insults.

deliberation: The verse recounts 'the evils' of ancestors, kings, and wives in literal historical terms, with geography ('in the land of Judah and streets of Jerusalem') also literal. No metaphorical or idiomatic expression is prominent here beyond standard moral terminology.

Observed two figurative expressions: (1) 'they were not crushed/humbled' (לֹא דֻכְּאוּ) depicting contrition as being 'crushed', and (2) 'they did not walk in My Teaching and My laws' (לֹא־הָלְכוּ בְתֽוֹרָתִי) using the conventional 'walk' metaphor for one's way of life in relation to Torah.

instances.english_text: no one has shown contrition (lit. 'they were not crushed')
vehicle: an object being crushed or broken
ground: contrition feels like being broken or shattered
loss of pride and self-sufficiency
embodied experience of being pressed down
posture: laments their lack of inward brokenness over sin
instances.explanation: The puʿal of דכא pictures true repentance as being 'crushed', a metaphor conveying deep inner humbling that has not occurred.

instances.english_text: and they did not walk in My Teaching and My laws
target: their pattern of conduct vis-à-vis God's commands
ground: life as a path; conduct as the route one walks
direction, continuity, and choice of 'way'
shared experience of following or deviating from a path
posture: frames obedience as staying on the path laid out by God
instances.explanation: Using 'walk in my Torah' conceptualizes their behavior as a path they should traverse but have refused, a standard ethical metaphor in Hebrew.

deliberation: The key idiom is 'I am setting My face against you for evil' (הִנְנִי שָׂם פָּנַי בָּכֶם לְרָעָה). This pictures divine disfavor as the orientation of God's 'face' toward them for harm, an anthropomorphic metaphor.

instances.english_text: I am going to set My face against you for punishment
vehicle: a person's face turned against someone
ground: where one turns their face signals favor or hostility
intentional focus directed toward another
shared social cue of turning one's face against someone
posture: announces God's deliberate opposition to them
instances.explanation: God's 'face' oriented 'against' them metaphorically represents His resolved, hostile judicial attitude toward Judah.

deliberation: Found three distinct devices: (1) 'who set their faces to come to Egypt' (אֲשֶׁר־שָׂמוּ פְנֵיהֶם לָבוֹא) as an idiom for determined intent, (2) 'from small to great' (מִקָּטֹן וְעַד־גָּדוֹל) as a merism for everyone, and (3) 'they shall be for an oath, a desolation, a curse, and a reproach' (לְאָלָה לְשַׁמָּה וְלִקְלָלָה וּלְחֶרְפָּה) as metonymic language for becoming proverbial objects of cursing and horror.

instances.english_text: who turned/set their faces toward the land of Egypt, to go there
target: their decision to emigrate to Egypt
vehicle: orienting one's face in a direction
ground: where you face shows where you intend to go
bodily orientation as indicator of determined intention
shared embodied cue of 'setting one's face'
posture: portrays their move to Egypt as a deliberate, resolute act
instances.explanation: To 'set one's face' toward a place is an idiomatic metaphor for firm determination to go there.

instances.english_text: great and small alike (lit. 'from small and up to great')
target: all individuals in the remnant group
vehicle: size contrast between small and great
ground: covering both extremes implies including everyone in between
use of opposites to signal totality
common rhetorical merism
posture: stresses that no social rank will escape judgment
instances.explanation: The phrase uses small/great as a merism to express that every person, regardless of status, will be affected.

instances.english_text: and they shall become an execration, a desolation, a curse, and a mockery
target: their remembered fate among other peoples
vehicle: oath-curse, horror, curse, reproach as labels or bywords
ground: becoming the stock example invoked in oaths, horror stories, and insults
identity reduced to a proverb of doom
shared practice of citing notorious disasters as warnings
posture: threatens that their story will serve as a negative paradigm to others
instances.explanation: Being 'for an oath, a desolation, a curse, and a reproach' means others will use their fate as a metonymic label in swearing, shuddering, cursing, and mocking.

deliberation: Checked whether 'I will punish (פָּקַדְתִּי) ... with the sword, with famine, and with pestilence' used metaphorical imagery. Here 'sword, famine, pestilence' function as the actual means of judgment, in a well-known triad, but not in a clearly figurative or personified way in this verse. Chose to treat the language as essentially literal-prophetic.

The key idiom is 'who are lifting up their souls to return' (אֲשֶׁר־הֵמָּה מְנַשְּׂאִים אֶת־נַפְשָׁם לָשׁוּב), a common Hebrew metaphor for intense desire or aspiration. No other strong figures besides standard 'remnant' language.

instances.english_text: who long to return (lit. 'who are lifting up their souls to return')
target: their strong longing to return to Judah
ground: intense desire felt as a 'lifted-up' inner self reaching toward a goal
upward movement as aspiration
shared association of elevation with longing and hope
posture: acknowledges their strong yearning but denies its fulfillment
instances.explanation: The idiom 'lift up the soul' portrays their desire to return as their inner self being elevated toward that aim.

deliberation: Describes the speakers (men, women, all the people in Pathros) in straightforward narrative form. No metaphorical, personifying, or idiomatic expressions stand out; the cultic actions are literal.

The refusal 'we will not listen to you' (אֵינֶנּוּ שֹׁמְעִים אֵלֶיךָ) is literal, though 'listen' often implies 'obey'. Here it does not rise above normal semantic extension into a distinct figure; no marked metaphor or idiom beyond that.

Examined possible idioms: 'we had plenty to eat and were well-off' is literal. The phrase 'and we saw no evil' (וְרָעָה לֹא רָאִינוּ) uses 'see evil' as an idiom for experiencing misfortune, a mild metaphorical expression.

instances.english_text: and we suffered no misfortune (lit. 'we did not see evil')
target: their experience of calamity or trouble
ground: to experience something is like 'seeing' it
visibility as metaphor for encounter
shared expression 'to see trouble' meaning to undergo it
posture: asserts that under the Queen of Heaven's worship they did not encounter disaster
instances.explanation: The idiom 'not see evil' uses visual perception as a metaphor for experiencing calamity, claiming they did not encounter misfortune during that period.

deliberation: Noted two elements: (1) 'we have lacked everything' (חָסַרְנוּ כֹל) as rhetorical overstatement/hyperbole of deprivation, and (2) 'we have been finished/consumed by the sword and by famine' (וּבַחֶרֶב וּבָרָעָב תָּמְנוּ), where 'sword' and 'famine' stand metonymically for war-related death and deprivation.

instances.english_text: we have lacked everything
ground: intensely perceived deprivation is described as lacking 'everything'
emotional exaggeration to stress hardship
shared rhetorical overstatement of want
posture: dramatizes their hardship to defend continued idolatry
instances.explanation: Claiming they have 'lacked everything' overstates their deprivation for rhetorical effect, functioning as hyperbole.

instances.english_text: we have been consumed by the sword and by famine
target: their deaths and losses in war and scarcity
vehicle: the 'sword' and 'famine' as agents that consume people
weapons and scarcity personified as killers
ground: warfare and hunger are primary causes of death in crisis
sword and famine encapsulate the violent and privational aspects of judgment
common prophetic metonymy for war and siege conditions
posture: interprets their suffering as connected to cessation of goddess worship, but still uses prophetic death language
instances.explanation: The 'sword' stands metonymically for warfare, and 'famine' for starvation; they are personified as consuming agents that have finished them off.

deliberation: Their question about making cakes in the Queen of Heaven's likeness and pouring libations is cultically literal. The focus is on whether they acted with their husbands' approval. No clear metaphor, idiom, or personification appears.
Narrative framing of Jeremiah's response ('Jeremiah said to all the people...') without idiomatic or figurative turns. Speech and participants are described literally.

Two ideas appear, but one is strongly figurative: 'YHWH remembered and it came up on His heart' (אֹתָם זָכַר יְהוָה וַתַּעֲלֶה עַל־לִבּוֹ). The movement 'up onto the heart' is an anthropopathic metaphor for God taking something into His inner regard; it is the main figure here.

instances.english_text: they were remembered by GOD and brought to mind (lit. 'and it came up onto His heart')
target: God's internal attention to their idolatrous offerings
vehicle: things rising up onto a person's heart
inner organ as seat of thought/emotion
ground: to consider something deeply is to have it on one’s heart
movement 'up' to the heart signals focus and concern
shared embodiment where heart symbolizes inner self
posture: portrays their sins as coming fully into God's conscious regard, prompting judgment
instances.explanation: The idiom of something 'coming up onto the heart' anthropomorphically depicts God as a human whose inner self is preoccupied with remembered offenses.

deliberation: Detected: (1) 'YHWH could no longer bear' (לֹא־יוּכַל יְהוָה עוֹד לָשֵׂאת) as an anthropopathic metaphor for God being unable to tolerate their evil any more, and (2) 'your land became a desolate ruin and a curse' (וַתְּהִי אַרְצְכֶם לְחָרְבָּה וּלְשַׁמָּה וְלִקְלָלָה) where 'a curse' again metonymically signifies becoming a negative example in others' speech.

instances.english_text: When GOD could no longer bear [it]
target: God's tolerance threshold regarding their sins
vehicle: a person bearing/carrying a burden until it becomes too heavy
ground: persistent evil is like an increasing weight
eventual collapse under an unbearable load
shared experience of 'not being able to carry more'
posture: stresses the extreme, intolerable nature of their abominations
instances.explanation: The phrase likens God's forbearance to a person carrying a heavy burden who finally cannot carry it any longer, an anthropopathic metaphor for the end of divine patience.

instances.english_text: your land became a desolate ruin and a curse
target: the status and reputation of the land of Judah
vehicle: a 'curse' as a label used in imprecations
desolation and horror as paradigmatic states
ground: the devastated land becomes an emblem cited in curses and horror tales
identity collapsed into being a byword of ruin
shared practice of invoking ruined places as warnings
posture: underscores that Judah has become a proverb of disaster
instances.explanation: Calling the land 'a curse' means it serves metonymically as an example invoked in the curses and fearful speech of others, not that the land literally transforms into a spoken curse.

deliberation: Reviewed 'this disaster has befallen you' (קָרָאת אֶתְכֶם הָרָעָה) and other phrasing; here 'evil' again means calamity. The idiom 'befall' is standard and not strongly pictorial in this context. Overall, the verse summarizes causality in relatively literal legal-theological language.

A direct address ('Hear the word of YHWH') to all Judah in Egypt. 'Hear' carries its typical connotation of 'obey', but this is standard covenant idiom rather than a marked figurative expression in this verse. No distinct metaphor or personification detected.

Identified 'with your mouths you spoke, and with your hands you fulfilled [it]' (וַתְּדַבֵּרְנָה בְּפִיכֶם וּבִידֵיכֶם מִלֵּאתֶם) as synecdochic and idiomatic: 'mouth' and 'hand' stand for word and deed, and 'fill with the hand' is a metaphor for carrying out what was said.

instances.english_text: you spoke with your mouths and fulfilled it with your hands
target: their verbal vows and corresponding actions
vehicle: mouth as instrument of speech; hand as instrument of action
ground: what the mouth says and the hand does represent the whole person’s commitment
speech–deed alignment
shared embodiment where mouth/hand typify word and work
posture: indicts them for fully enacting their idolatrous vows in both word and deed
prophetic exposure of consistency in evil
instances.explanation: The verse uses mouth and hand metonymically for their speech and actions, and 'you filled it with your hands' metaphorically for bringing their words to full realization through deeds.

deliberation: Key figurative element: 'by My great name' and 'if My name shall ever again be invoked in the mouth of any man of Judah' (שְׁמִי ... נִקְרָא ... בְּפִי כׇּל־אִישׁ יְהוּדָה). 'Name' functions metonymically for God's person and authority, and 'be called in the mouth' is idiomatic for oath invocation.

instances.hebrew_text: בִּשְׁמִי הַגָּדוֹל ... שְׁמִי נִקְרָא ... בְּפִי כׇּל־אִישׁ יְהוּדָה
instances.english_text: by My great name ... that none of Judah shall ever again invoke My name, saying, 'As my Sovereign GOD lives!'
target: God Himself and His authority as invoked in oaths
vehicle: God's 'name' as the object uttered in the mouth
ground: uttering the name stands for appealing to the person and authority behind it
name as metonym for identity
shared human practice of using names as proxies for persons/power
posture: announces a ban on invoking YHWH in oaths, marking relational severance
instances.explanation: Here 'My name' stands metonymically for God Himself and His authority; the prohibition that His name be 'called in the mouth' forbids any appeal to Him in oaths.

deliberation: Detected two figures: (1) 'I am watching over them for evil and not for good' (הִנְנִי שֹׁקֵד עֲלֵיהֶם לְרָעָה וְלֹא לְטוֹבָה) as a metaphor (and ironic reversal) of the typical image of God watching over for good, and (2) 'by the sword and by famine' again using 'sword' and 'famine' metonymically and with slight personification as agents of consumption.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנְנִי שֹׁקֵד עֲלֵיהֶם לְרָעָה וְלֹא לְטוֹבָה
instances.english_text: I will be watchful over them to their hurt, not to their benefit
target: God's active providential engagement with Judah in Egypt
vehicle: a watchful guardian or caretaker, but for harm
ground: constant attention and supervision can be directed for good or ill
ironic flip of expected benevolent watchcare
shared sense of being 'watched over' by authorities
posture: ironically inverts the usual promise of watchful care, announcing vigilant supervision for their ruin
instances.explanation: The verb 'watching over' evokes a guardian's care, but here God declares He will exercise that vigilance to ensure their harm, an ironic metaphor contrasting with earlier assurances of watchcare for good.

instances.english_text: by sword and by famine, until they cease to be
target: the means and process of their destruction
vehicle: 'sword' and 'famine' as actors that consume people
weapons and scarcity functioning as killers
ground: warfare and hunger are the main causes of mass death in such crises
sword and famine encapsulate two facets of judgment
shared recognition of these as stock agents of disaster
posture: specifies that God’s negative oversight will work through these classic agents of judgment
instances.explanation: Here the 'sword' stands metonymically for warfare, and 'famine' for hunger; both are personified as instruments that bring about their end.

deliberation: Observed two figures: (1) 'survivors of the sword' (פְּלִיטֵי חֶרֶב) again using 'sword' as synecdoche/metonymy for warfare, and (2) 'whose word will stand' (דְּבַר־מִי יָקוּם) using 'stand' as a metaphor for being fulfilled or proven true.

instances.english_text: Only the few who survive the sword shall return
vehicle: weapon representing the whole combat scenario
ground: dying 'by the sword' is emblematic of wartime death
the weapon stands for the context and process of killing
common synecdoche in Hebrew war language
posture: underscores that only a tiny remnant will outlive the violence
instances.explanation: Calling them 'survivors of the sword' uses the sword metonymically and synecdochically for warfare and its lethal force.

instances.english_text: whose word will be fulfilled—Mine or theirs (lit. 'whose word will stand, from Me or from them')
target: the competing claims about what will happen
ground: what 'stands' is firm, realized, enduring; what falls does not endure
fulfillment is pictured as successful standing
shared sense of standing as metaphor for validity
posture: casts the issue as a contest of which word will prove enduringly true
prophetic assertion of God's word over against human claims
instances.explanation: The idiom of a 'word' that 'stands' depicts the fulfillment and enduring truth of a prediction as if it were an object that successfully remains upright.

deliberation: Primary figure: 'that My words will surely stand against you for evil' (כִּי קוֹם יָקוּמוּ דְבָרַי עֲלֵיכֶם לְרָעָה), again using the 'standing' metaphor for the firm realization of God's threat, now explicitly in the form of a sign.

instances.english_text: that My threats of punishment against you will be fulfilled (lit. 'surely My words will stand against you for evil')
vehicle: upright, established objects pressing on a person
ground: firmly standing evokes stability, reality, and effectiveness
a word that stands over someone exerts force
shared metaphor of standing for established fact
posture: emphasizes the certainty and effective imposition of His threats
instances.explanation: Again God's words are portrayed as something that 'stands', picturing their threats as firmly established realities that will press upon the people.

deliberation: Found two idiomatic-metaphoric phrases: (1) 'into the hand of his enemies' (בְּיַד אֹיְבָיו) where 'hand' stands for power/control, and (2) 'those who seek his life' (מְבַקְשֵׁי נַפְשׁוֹ) as an idiom for those seeking to kill him, not merely to 'find' his life in a neutral sense.

instances.english_text: into the hands of his enemies
target: Pharaoh Hophra's political fate and subjugation
vehicle: the 'hand' as locus of power and control
ground: being in someone's hand indicates being under their power
hand as the instrument of seizure and control
shared embodied sense of grasping as domination
posture: announces Pharaoh's defeat and subjection to his foes
theology of God's control of rulers
instances.explanation: The 'hand' of enemies metonymically represents their power; to be given into their hand is to fall under their control.

instances.english_text: those who seek his life
vehicle: searching as if for an object to obtain
ground: actively attempting to kill someone is conceptualized as 'seeking their life'
life as an object that can be taken by those who seek it
shared idiom for murderous intent
posture: frames his enemies as relentless pursuers aiming at his very life
instances.explanation: The idiom 'seek his life' uses 'life' metonymically for the person’s continued existence, depicting those who aim to kill him as pursuing his life.
